SENT.plain: INTRODUCTION: Sturge-Weber syndrome is characterized by capillary malformations in the face, associated with leptomeningeal and choroidal venous malformations
Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome consists of the triad: capillary malformation of one leg, ipsilateral hypertrophy and varicose veins

OBSERVATION: We report the case of a 23-year-old male patient who presented a complex congenital neurocutaneous syndrome with vascular malformations involving the brain, face and limbs and associated with epilepsia and leptomeningeal calcifications
The patient fulfilled the diagnostic criteria of both vascular phacomatosis syndromes
DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSION: Similar descriptions of dual or overlapping syndromes have been published
Many show that there is no clear distinction between Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome and Sturge-Weber syndrome
There is a clinical and biological overlap
The complexity of the disease phenotypes shows that a classification based on an eponymous category does not enable resolution of the nosological problems
Some authors suggest that these vascular malformations are best described in anatomical/histological or functional terms
We report a new observation that illustrates these difficulties
